content: The "National Mental Health Parity Act of 1999" is also known as the "Parity for Treatment of Mental Illness" Act. It amends the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to include provisions for parity in the treatment of mental illness. The "National Mental Health Parity Act of 1999" imposes a 25 percent tax on health insurance coverage and group health plans that fail to meet certain standards. The "National Mental Health Parity Act of 1999" imposes a 25 percent tax on group health plans for failing to meet certain standards. The tax is equal to 25 percent of health coverage expenditures for the calendar year under the plan, to be paid by the group health plan. The tax is not imposed if it is proven to the Secretary that the failure was not discovered despite reasonable diligence. The Secretary may waive the tax if it is shown that the failure to meet standards was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect, and if the failure is corrected within 30 days of discovery. The Secretary may waive the tax if the failure to meet standards was due to reasonable cause and not willful neglect. Health insurance issuers and group health plans cannot impose additional restrictions on mental illness coverage compared to other conditions. Health insurance issuers and group health plans can require preadmission screening for mental illness coverage, as long as it is medically necessary. Mental illness is defined as clinical and personality disorders, excluding mental retardation. The recent edition of the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders provides definitions for terms related to health insurance coverage, including health insurance coverage, health insurance issuer, and group health plan. A clerical amendment was made to the Code to reflect these definitions. SEC. 102 of the document specifies the effective date for the amendment related to mental illness treatment in health insurance coverage and group health plans. SEC. 201 and SEC. 202 focus on references in the title and inpatient psychiatric hospital services, respectively. The amendment expands coverage for inpatient hospital services related to mental illness or substance abuse for up to 60 days per year. It also limits coverage to 60 days per year after initial services have been provided. Individuals receiving inpatient psychiatric hospital services before this date may have limitations on entitlement to services under section 1812(a)(5) of the Social Security Act. The entitlement to inpatient psychiatric hospital services under section 1812(a)(5) of the Social Security Act is determined by the greater of 60 days or the difference between 190 days and the number of days of services received before January 1, 2000. SEC. 203. INTENSIVE RESIDENTIAL SERVICES. Intensive residential services can now be provided to an individual for up to 120 days in a calendar year, with the possibility of additional days if needed to complete treatment, as long as the individual receives at least 15 days of inpatient hospital services.
